sentence.text: Nuclear respiratory factor 1 (positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated) transcription factor has recently been shown to control breast cancer progression.
However, mechanistic aspects by which positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated may contribute to susceptibility to different breast tumor subtypes are still not fully understood.

Since transcriptional control of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated seems to be dependent on epidermal growth factor receptor signaling, herein, we investigated the role of NRF1 in estrogen receptor/progesterone receptor negative, but human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive (ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve) breast cancer.

We found that both mRNA and protein levels of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated and its transcriptional activity were significantly higher in ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve breast cancer samples compared to normal breast tissues.

This was consistent with our observation of higher positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated protein expression in the experimental model of signal transduction+ breast cancer brain metastasis.

To identify network-based pathways involved in the susceptibility to the ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve breast cancer subtype, the positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated transcriptional regulatory genome-wide landscape was analyzed using the approach consisting of a systematic integration of protein polyubiquitination DNA-seq, RNA-Microarray, NRF1 protein-DNA motif binding, signal pathway analysis, and Bayesian machine learning.

Our findings show that a high percentage of known signal transduction+ breast cancer susceptibility genes, including positive regulation of protein phosphorylation, negative regulation of apoptotic process, and regulation of transcription, DNA-templated, are under transcriptional control of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated.

Promoters of several genes from the KEGG signal transduction+ breast cancer pathway and 11 signaling pathways linked to 6 hallmarks of cancer contain the positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated motif.

By pathway analysis, key breast cancer hallmark genes of epithelial-mesenchymal transition, stemness, cell apoptosis, cell cycle regulation, chromosomal integrity, and DNA damage/repair were highly enriched with positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated motifs.

In addition, we found using Bayesian network-based machine learning that 30 positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated motif-enriched genes including growth factor receptors-positive regulation of cell proliferation, negative regulation of apoptotic process; E2Fs transcription factor family-regulation of transcription, DNA-templated, E2F3; MAPK pathway-MAPK cascade, insulin receptor signaling pathway, protein phosphorylation; phosphorylation-AKT-regulation of cell growth signaling pathway-phosphorylation, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase signaling, positive regulation of protein phosphorylation, positive regulation of translational initiation; WNT signaling pathway-canonical Wnt signaling pathway, DLV1, DLV2, regulation of synaptic vesicle exocytosis, NRF1, and protein polyubiquitination, known for its role in DNA repair and involvement in early events associated with metastatic progression of breast cancer cells, were associated with signal transduction-amplified breast cancer.

Machine learning search further revealed that the likelihood of signal transduction-positive breast cancer is almost 100% in a patient with the high positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated expression combined with expression patterns of high E2F3, regulation of synaptic vesicle exocytosis, and protein phosphorylation, low or no change in regulation of transcription, DNA-templated and positive regulation of cell proliferation, and high or no change in positive regulation of protein phosphorylation.

In summary, our findings suggest novel roles of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated and its regulatory networks in susceptibility to the ER/PR -ve signal transduction +ve aggressive breast cancer subtype.

Clinical confirmation of our machine learned Bayesian networks will have significant impact on our understanding of the role of positive regulation of transcription, DNA-templated as a valuable biomarker for breast cancer diagnosis and prognosis as well as provide strong rationale for future studies to develop NRF1 signaling-based therapeutics to target signal transduction+ breast cancer
